awd_titl_txt: Ambient and Source Characterization of Aerosol Size and Composition in Nepal and Bhutan using High-Resolution Aerosol Mass Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is part of a larger collaborative project funded by NSF (Lead Proposal AGS-1349976) to develop new atmospheric emission factors for under-sampled sources in South Asia of aerosols and trace gases of global significance. Better estimates of aerosol and gas emissions are important for predicting changes in air quality and climate that might result from future economic development in Asia. Improved emission factors also will be used in regional chemical transport models to assess various pollution mitigation strategies for the region.

Two aerosol mass spectrometers (AMS) will be deployed to Nepal and Bhutan and be the first use of sophisticated AMS instrumentation in the region. The instruments will be divided between fixed site measurements (using a Soot-Particle Aerosol Mass Spectrometer, SP-AMS) and direct source measurements (using a mini-Aerosol Mass Spectrometer, mAMS). The objectives of the research are to: (1) characterize and quantify the submicron aerosol composition, sources, secondary formation, and daily trends using a soot-particle aerosol mass spectrometer in the context of other complementary measurements from ambient fixed site monitoring in Katmandu, Nepal; (2) apportion sources of organic aerosol, light absorbing carbonaceous components, and metallic species in ambient aerosol using techniques such as positive matrix factorization; and (3) conduct source characterization and mass spectral fingerprinting of under-sampled combustion sources(e.g. garbage burning, brick kilns, etc.) using a mini-Aerosol Mass Spectrometer in addition to the current suite of instruments funded for this work.  The PI will also evaluate the ratio of oxidized organic aerosol to odd-oxygen to help understand and/or bound the secondary organic aerosol formation potential in this region.

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled a multi-university collaboration with scientists and organizations in Nepal to study the air pollution issues of the Kathmandu Valley and the border region of Nepal with India.  This study began with measurements of air pollution sources that are relevant to the Nepal region including emissions from brick kilns, trash burning, agricultural burning, vehicle emissions, and home cooking.  We also started the measurement of general air quality in the Kathmandu Valley at a location between the city of Kathmandu and the more industrial region with many brick kilns.  Unfortunately, our measurement project was cut short due to the large earthquake in April of 2015.  After 2.5 year, we were able to return and complete our measurements of ambient air quality in Nepal, including 4 additional measurement sites, with 3 of them in the Kathmandu Valley and 1 site in Lumbini in the border region with India.  The measurements focused on the chemical measurement of particles in the air, which allow the research team to identify the sources of air pollution in the places in which measurements were made.  In the Kathmandu Valley, we find that it is a mix of home burning of trash and fuel for cooking and heating, traffic, and brick kilns as large contributors to air pollution. We also found that air pollution varies across the valley with some areas more impacted by the sources that are close by indicating that multiple measurement sites are necessary to better understand air pollution exposures across a metropolitan area.

In addition to the scientific results of this study, it also served to improve and strengthen multi-national research collaborations with scientists at the International Center for Integrated Mountain Development and train the next generation of scientists including an undergraduate student (now a Ph.D. candidate), 2 graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher.  Results from this project have also led to the PI becoming the Air Quality Fellow for the US Department of State for the Nepal Embassy in Kathmandu.  As the AQ Fellow, he has communicated the results of this broader study to USAID and State Department projects in the South Asian region, and is often called upon to share expertise gained through this research with stakeholders in Nepal further broadening the impact of this work for the region.
